awd_titl_txt: On the Mathematical Theory of Black Holes
awd_abstract_narration:
At the most basic level Black Holes are  nothing  but  special, explicit,  solutions  of the  Einstein equations of General Relativity.  To have  physical reality  they have to possess  properties  which  make them detectable to observations. Chief among them is stability to perturbations. This translates to a very difficult, deep and beautiful mathematical conjecture which is the main  focus of the proposed   research.  The goal is to show that any  small perturbation, at a given time, of a given black hole solution remains small for all later  times. Thus all the important features of a unperturbed black hole are preserved by the perturbations.

To solve the problem of stability of black holes one has to overcome a large range of difficult issues. The high non-linearity of the Einstein  equations makes it hard to separate them; they are all interconnected.  At the heart of all these difficulties is the issue of gauge. That means, roughly,  that one cannot solve the stability problem without finding a specific coordinate system  in which  one can  establish decay of the perturbations, i.e. to show that the perturbations converge to zero for large times. In collaboration with J. Szeftel in France the PI had proposed a new method to construct these coordinates  based on the full covariance properties of the  Einstein equations. The main methodology of the PI is to combine this new method, called Generally Covariant Modulation theory, with the the so called vector-field method.

por.por_cntn:
The   main outcome of the  NSF grant  is a complete   proof of the nonlinear stability  of Black Holes  with small angular momentum.  This   resolves  a long standing  problem in  General Relativity  which goes back to the revolutionary discovery  of  black holes, first by Schwarzschild  in 1916- a few month after Einstein's formulation of General Relativity in November 1915,  and then by Kerr in 1963. Kerr discovered a two parameter family of stationary  solutions  to  the Einstein field equations which  forms  the theoretical  basis of our understanding  of  black holes-  considered  to be    the most  fascinating   and mysterious physical objects in the  universe.   The discovery of these solutions  led to an enormous  interest in the question of their stability, that is the question of their  stability relative to arbitrary small perturbations.  It goes  without saying that this is a fundamental problem for, if black holes  where unstable, they would be merely mathematical artifacts  devoid of phsyical meaning. The problem, which  has  drawn  the attention of both  theoretical physicists  and mathematicians,  has  required  the development of new mathematical  ideas  and techniques which are expected to be important in other problems of mathematical physics.

 

A first important   step was the proof of the nonlinear stability of the Minkowsky space established  by Christodoulou and Klainerman  more that 30 years ago.  That work is considered foundational  for  the  field which is known as mathematical  relativity. The next big step   was the  proof of the nonlinear stability of the Schwarzschild  space  under polarized perturbations  established by the principal investigator PI  in collaboration with Jeremie Szeftel from France. This work has  appeared as a book published  by  Princeton University Press  in 2020.  In April this year the PI and Szeftel have  submitted   on arXiv the main part of a  full proof  of the nonlinear stability of  the Kerr fanily of  black holes with small angular rotation. Thety expect to publish   the  remaining part  at the beginning of 2022.  The  proof of the stability of the  full family of acceptable Kerr black holes  remains open but  the PI expects  that  most ideas are already in place   and expect that the full result  will be available  during the  decade.
